content.webTitle: Mo Farah leads gold rush to give Britain a flying start in Zurich

fields.headline: Mo Farah leads gold rush to give British athletics perfect start in Zurich
fields.bodyText: British athletics is celebrating its most successful start to a European Championships after six medals on the second day – including golds for Mo Farah in the 10,000m, James Dasaolu in the 100m and Tiffany Porter in the 100m hurdles – took them top of the medal table. On a wet but wonderful Wednesday in Zurich Jo Pavey also received her women’s 10,000m gold, while there was a silver medal for Andy Vernon in the men’s 10,000m with bronzes for Harry Aikines-Aryeetey and Ashleigh Nelson in the men’s and women’s 100m respectively. As Porter put it afterwards: “What we’ve done so far is really special. On Tuesday what Jo did spurred us on and Mo’s victory before I raced also gave me a boost.” Britain has never finished top of the medal table at the European Championships but Porter cited the pre-event talk given by the team’s captain, Goldie Sayers, who urged every athlete competing to go out and compete as if it was their last championships, as inspiring them to greater heights. Farah’s victory got the evening off to the perfect start and, while it was not a vintage performance from Britain’s most successful middle-distance athlete, he was delighted to claim gold after a wretched six months during which he has collapsed twice and disappointed at the London marathon. “To come out here and win it meant a lot to me, more than anything else in the world in terms of medals,” he said. “It’s probably close to the Olympics because only three weeks ago I had to pull out of the Commonwealth Games and things weren’t going so well.” Afterwards Farah hugged his friend Usain Bolt, who had a front-row seat as Dasaolu won the 100m in a modest 10.06sec into a slight headwind. “This is a lovely feeling,” admitted the 26-year-old from south London. “If I roll the clock back to February, I pulled my hamstring and didn’t know if I was going to have a season. Fast-forward to Zurich and now I’m European champion. It’s been a dream end to my season and I just hope to use it as a platform to achieve better things in the future.” Meanwhile Porter, who came under criticism from some quarters when she switched allegiance from America to Britain before the London 2012 Olympics, was also delighted with her first gold medal. “That was my aim at the beginning of the season, so I’m very happy,” she said.
